title: How to Cook Adobong Pusit

steps.headline: Rinse 2 pounds (910 g) of squid and remove the ink sacs.
steps.description: Locate the head of the squid and pull it to remove the long flexible quill. Discard this, but keep the tentacles. Carefully remove the tiny ink sac. Reserve the ink sacs to add right before serving. If one bursts, scrape the ink into a bowl to save it. You don't need to cut the squid for this recipe.

steps.headline: Bring the soy sauce, vinegar, and water to a boil.
steps.description: Pour ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of soy sauce into a wok and add ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of vinegar along with 1 cup (240 ml) of water. Turn the burner to high and bring the liquids to a boil. If you don't have a wok, you can use a deep skillet.

steps.headline: Add the squid and simmer it for 5 minutes over medium heat.
steps.description: Stir the cleaned squid into the wok and turn the burner down to medium. The liquid should be bubbling gently.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and separate the squid from the liquid.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to scoop up the squid and place it into a bowl. Pour the liquid into a separate bowl and set both bowls aside.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion, tomatoes, and garlic for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Heat 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of vegetable oil in another wok over medium heat. Dice 1 large onion and 2 medium tomatoes. Add these to the hot oil along with 5 cloves of crushed garlic. Stir the vegetables as they cook or they will stick to the wok.

steps.headline: Simmer the squid with the vegetables and liquid for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Add the squid and cook it for 30 seconds. Then pour in the liquid and bring it a boil. Once the liquid boils vigorously, turn the burner down to medium so it bubbles gently. Stir the squid occasionally as it simmers.

steps.headline: Stir in sugar, salt, pepper, and the reserved ink.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon (4 g) of sugar and salt and pepper according to your to taste. Stir in the reserved ink sacs from the squids. The liquid should quickly become dark.

steps.headline: Simmer the adobong pusit for 3 minutes before serving.
steps.description: Let the squid bubble gently for a few minutes before you turn off the burner. Serve the adobong pusit with steamed white rice. Store the leftover adobong pusit in an airtight container for up to 3 or 4 days.

methods.name: Making Adobong Pusit with Coconut Milk and Ginger

steps.headline: Trim 2 pounds (910 g) of squid and remove the ink sacs.
steps.description: Rinse the squid and find the head. Pull the head to remove the long flexible quill and throw it away. Keep the tentacles and remove the ink sac carefully so the ink doesn't stain your fingers. Use the ink sacs in another recipe or discard them. If you aren't using baby squid, slice the squid into 1 in (2.5 cm) rings.

steps.headline: Bring the squid, garlic, vinegar, and bay leaf to a boil for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Put the squid into a large pot and stir in 2 cloves of minced garlic, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of vinegar, and 1 bay leaf. Turn the burner to medium-high and bring the liquid to a boil. The squid should turn white and dark purple.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and reserve 1 cup (240 ml) of the liquid.
steps.description: Set a fine mesh strainer over a bowl. Pour the squid and liquid through the strainer. Measure 1 cup (240 ml) of the liquid and set it aside. Discard the rest of the liquid. Set the squid aside while you sauté the onion and peppers.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion, ginger, peppers, and garlic for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Heat 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of vegetable oil in another pot over medium heat. When the oil shimmers, stir in 1 thinly sliced onion, 1 to 2 minced Thai chili peppers, 1 in (2.5 cm) of thinly sliced ginger, and the remaining 2 cloves of minced garlic. Stir the vegetables as they cook so they don't stick to the bottom of the pot.

steps.headline: Add the tomatoes with fish sauce and simmer it for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: Chop 2 tomatoes and add them to the pot with the sautéed vegetables. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of fish sauce and cook the mixture until the tomatoes become soft.

steps.headline: Stir in the coconut milk and reserved squid liquid.
steps.description: Bring the liquid to a gentle boil and let it cook until you see some of the fat from the coconut liquefy. Stir the pot to prevent the liquid from sticking.

steps.headline: Add the squid and cook it for 3 to 5 minutes before serving.
steps.description: Stir in the reserved squid along with salt and pepper to taste. Keep cooking the adobong pusit over medium heat until the squid is hot throughout. Serve the dish with steamed rice. Refrigerate the leftover squid in an airtight container for up to 3 or 4 days.

text: Cooking Classic Adobong Pusit Rinse 2 pounds (910 g) of squid and remove the ink sacs. Locate the head of the squid and pull it to remove the long flexible quill. Discard this, but keep the tentacles. Carefully remove the tiny ink sac. Reserve the ink sacs to add right before serving. If one bursts, scrape the ink into a bowl to save it. You don't need to cut the squid for this recipe. Bring the soy sauce, vinegar, and water to a boil. Pour ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of soy sauce into a wok and add ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of vinegar along with 1 cup (240 ml) of water. Turn the burner to high and bring the liquids to a boil. If you don't have a wok, you can use a deep skillet. Add the squid and simmer it for 5 minutes over medium heat. Stir the cleaned squid into the wok and turn the burner down to medium. The liquid should be bubbling gently. Turn off the burner and separate the squid from the liquid. Use a slotted spoon to scoop up the squid and place it into a bowl. Pour the liquid into a separate bowl and set both bowls aside. Sauté the onion, tomatoes, and garlic for 2 to 3 minutes. Heat 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of vegetable oil in another wok over medium heat. Dice 1 large onion and 2 medium tomatoes. Add these to the hot oil along with 5 cloves of crushed garlic. Stir the vegetables as they cook or they will stick to the wok. Simmer the squid with the vegetables and liquid for 3 minutes. Add the squid and cook it for 30 seconds. Then pour in the liquid and bring it a boil. Once the liquid boils vigorously, turn the burner down to medium so it bubbles gently. Stir the squid occasionally as it simmers. Stir in sugar, salt, pepper, and the reserved ink. Add 1 teaspoon (4 g) of sugar and salt and pepper according to your to taste. Stir in the reserved ink sacs from the squids. The liquid should quickly become dark. Simmer the adobong pusit for 3 minutes before serving. Let the squid bubble gently for a few minutes before you turn off the burner. Serve the adobong pusit with steamed white rice. Store the leftover adobong pusit in an airtight container for up to 3 or 4 days. Making Adobong Pusit with Coconut Milk and Ginger Trim 2 pounds (910 g) of squid and remove the ink sacs. Rinse the squid and find the head. Pull the head to remove the long flexible quill and throw it away. Keep the tentacles and remove the ink sac carefully so the ink doesn't stain your fingers. Use the ink sacs in another recipe or discard them. If you aren't using baby squid, slice the squid into 1 in (2.5 cm) rings. Bring the squid, garlic, vinegar, and bay leaf to a boil for 3 to 5 minutes. Put the squid into a large pot and stir in 2 cloves of minced garlic, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of vinegar, and 1 bay leaf. Turn the burner to medium-high and bring the liquid to a boil. The squid should turn white and dark purple. Turn off the burner and reserve 1 cup (240 ml) of the liquid. Set a fine mesh strainer over a bowl. Pour the squid and liquid through the strainer. Measure 1 cup (240 ml) of the liquid and set it aside. Discard the rest of the liquid. Set the squid aside while you sauté the onion and peppers. Sauté the onion, ginger, peppers, and garlic for 2 to 3 minutes. Heat 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of vegetable oil in another pot over medium heat. When the oil shimmers, stir in 1 thinly sliced onion, 1 to 2 minced Thai chili peppers, 1 in (2.5 cm) of thinly sliced ginger, and the remaining 2 cloves of minced garlic. Stir the vegetables as they cook so they don't stick to the bottom of the pot. Add the tomatoes with fish sauce and simmer it for 1 to 2 minutes. Chop 2 tomatoes and add them to the pot with the sautéed vegetables. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of fish sauce and cook the mixture until the tomatoes become soft. Stir in the coconut milk and reserved squid liquid. Bring the liquid to a gentle boil and let it cook until you see some of the fat from the coconut liquefy. Stir the pot to prevent the liquid from sticking. Add the squid and cook it for 3 to 5 minutes before serving. Stir in the reserved squid along with salt and pepper to taste. Keep cooking the adobong pusit over medium heat until the squid is hot throughout. Serve the dish with steamed rice. Refrigerate the leftover squid in an airtight container for up to 3 or 4 days.
